My Id On Defensiveness

Posted on August 15, 2015 by Scott Alexander

I.

I’ll admit it – I’ve been unusually defensive lately. Defensive about Hallquist’s critique of rationalism, defensive about Matthews’ critique of effective altruism, and if you think that’s bad you should see my Tumblr.

Brienne noticed this and asked me why I was so defensive all the time, and I thought about it, and I realized that my id had a pretty good answer. I’m not sure I can fully endorse my id on this one, but it was a sufficiently complete and consistent picture that I thought it was worth laying out.

I like discussion, debate, and reasoned criticism. But a lot of arguments aren’t any of those things. They’re the style I describe as ethnic tension, where you try to associate something you don’t like with negative affect so that other people have an instinctive disgust reaction to it.

There are endless sources of negative affect you can use. You can accuse them of being “arrogant”, “fanatical”, “hateful”, “cultish” or “refusing to tolerate alternative opinions”. You can accuse them of condoning terrorism, or bullying, or violence, or rape. You can call them racist or sexist, you can call them neckbeards or fanboys. You can accuse them of being pseudoscientific denialist crackpots.

If you do this enough, the group gradually becomes disreputable. If you really do it enough, the group becomes so toxic that it becomes somewhere between a joke and a bogeyman. Their supporters will be banned on site from all decent online venues. News media will write hit pieces on them and refuse to ask for their side of the story because ‘we don’t want to give people like that a platform’. Their concerns will be turned into bingo cards for easy dismissal. People will make Facebook memes strawmanning them, and everyone will laugh in unison and say that yep, they’re totally like that. Anyone trying to correct the record will be met with an “Ew, gross, this place has gone so downhill that the [GROUP] is coming out of the woodwork!” and totally ignored.

(an easy way to get a gut feeling for this – go check how they talk about liberals in very conservative communities, then go check how they talk about conservatives in very liberal communities. I’m talking about groups that somehow manage to gain this status everywhere simultaneously)

People like to talk a lot about “dehumanizing” other people, and there’s some debate over exactly what that entails. Me, I’ve always thought of it the same was as Aristotle: man is the rational animal. To dehumanize them is to say their ideas don’t count, they can’t be reasoned with, they no longer have a place at the table of rational discussion. And in a whole lot of Internet arguments, doing that to a whole group of people seems to be the explicit goal.

II.

There’s a term in psychoanalysis, “projective identification”. It means accusing someone of being something, in a way that actually turns them into that thing. For example, if you keep accusing your (perfectly innocent) partner of always being angry and suspicious of you, eventually your partner’s going to get tired of this and become angry, and maybe suspicious that something is up.

Declaring a group toxic has much the same effect. The average group has everyone from well-connected reasonable establishment members to average Joes to horrifying loonies. Once the group starts losing prestige, it’s the establishment members who are the first to bail; they need to protect their establishment credentials, and being part of a toxic group no longer fits that bill. The average Joes are now isolated, holding an opinion with no support among experts and trend-setters, so they slowly become uncomfortable and flake away as well. Now there are just the horrifying loonies, who, freed from the stabilizing influence of the upper orders, are able to up their game and be even loonier and more horrifying. Whatever accusation was leveled against the group to begin with is now almost certainly true.

I have about a dozen real-world examples of this, but all of them would be so mind-killing as to dominate the comments to the exclusion of my actual point, so generate them on your own and then shut up about them – in the meantime, I will use a total hypothetical. So consider Christianity.

Christianity has people like Alvin Plantinga and Ross Douthat who are clearly very respectable and key it into the great status-conferring institutions like academia and journalism. It has a bunch of middle-class teachers and plumbers and officer workers who go to church and raise money to send Bibles to Africa and try not to sin too much. And it has horrifying loons who stand on street corners waving signs saying “GOD HATES FAGS” and screaming about fornicators.

Imagine that Christianity suffers a sudden total dramatic in prestige, to the point where wearing a cross becomes about as socially acceptable as waving a Confederate flag. The New York Times fires Ross Douthat, because they can’t tolerate people like that on their editorial staff. The next Alvin Plantinga chooses a field other than philosophy of religion, because no college would consider granting him tenure for that.

With no Christians in public life or academia, Christianity starts to seem like a weird belief that intelligent people never support, much like homeopathy or creationism. The Christians have lost their air support, so to speak. The average college-educated individual starts to feel really awkward about this, and they don’t necessarily have to formally change their mind and grovel for forgiveness, they can just – go to church a little less, start saying they admire Jesus but they’re not Christian Christian, and so on.

Gradually the field is ceded more and more to the people waving signs and screaming about fornicators. The opponents of Christianity ramp up their attacks that all Christians are ignorant and hateful, and this is now a pretty hard charge to defend against, given the demographic. The few remaining moderates, being viewed suspiciously in churches that are now primarily sign-waver dominated and being genuinely embarrassed to be associated with them, bail at an increased rate, leading their comrades to bail at an even faster rate, until eventually it is entirely the sign wavers.

Then everybody agrees that their campaign against Christians was justified all along, because look how horrible Christians are, they’re all just a bunch of sign-wavers who have literally no redeeming features. Now even if the original pressure that started the attack on Christianity goes away, it’s inconceivable that it will ever come back – who would join a group that is universally and correctly associated with horrible ignorant people?

(I think this is sort of related to what Eliezer calls evaporative cooling of group beliefs, but not quite the same.)

In quite a number of the most toxic and hated groups around, I feel like I can trace a history where the group once had some pretty good points and pretty good people, until they were destroyed from the outside by precisely this process.

In Part I, I say that sometimes groups can get so swamped by other people’s insults that they turn toxic. There’s nothing in Part I to suggest that this would be any more than a temporary setback. But because of this projective identification issue, I think it’s way more than that. It’s more like there’s an event horizon, a certain amount of insulting and defamation you can take after which you will just get more and more hated and your reputation will never recover.

III.

There is some good criticism, where people discuss the ways that groups are factually wrong or not very helpful, and then those groups debate that, and then maybe everyone is better off.

But the criticism that makes me defensive is the type of criticism that seems to be trying to load groups with negative affect in the hopes of pushing them into that event horizon so that they’ll be hated forever.

I support some groups that are a little weird, and therefore especially vulnerable to having people try to push them into the event horizon.

And as far as I can tell, the best way to let that happen is to let other people load those groups with negative affect and do nothing about it. The average person doesn’t care whether the negative affect is right or wrong. They just care how many times they see the group’s name in close proximity to words like “crackpot” or “cult”.

I judge people based on how likely they are to do this to me. One reason I’m so reluctant to engage with feminists is that I feel like they constantly have a superweapon pointed at my head. Yes, many of them are very nice people who will never use the superweapon, but many others look like very nice people right up to the point where I disagree with them in earnest at which point they vaporize me and my entire social group.

On the other hand, you can push people into the event horizon, but you can’t pull them in after you. That means that the safest debate partners, the ones you can most productively engage, will be the people who have already been dismissed by everyone else. This is why I find talking to people like ClarkHat and JayMan so rewarding. They are already closer to the black hole than I am, and so they have no power to load me with negative affect or destroy my reputation. This reduces them to the extraordinary last resort of debating with actual facts and evidence. Even better, it gives me a credible reason to believe that they will. Schelling talks about “the right to be sued” as an important right that businesses need to protect for themselves, not because anyone likes being sued, but because only businesses that can be sued if they slip up have enough credibility to attract customers. In the same way, there’s a “right to be vulnerable to attack” which is almost a necessary precondition of interesting discussion these days, because only when we’re confronted with similarly vulnerable people can we feel comfortable opening up.

IV.

But with everybody else? I don’t know.

I remember seeing a blog post by a moderately-well known scholar – I can’t remember who he was or find the link, so you’ll just have to take my word for it – complaining that some other scholar in the field who disagreed with him was trying to ruin his reputation. Scholar B was publishing all this stuff falsely accusing Scholar A of misconduct, calling him a liar and a fraud, personally harassing him, and falsely accusing Scholar A of personally harassing him (Scholar B). This kinda went back and forth between both scholars’ blogs, and Scholar A wrote this heart-breaking post I still (sort of) remember, where he notes that he now has a reputation in his field for “being into drama” and “obsessed with defending himself” just because half of his blog posts are arguments presenting evidence that Scholar B’s fraudulent accusations are, indeed fraudulent.

It is really easy for me to see the path where rationalists and effective altruists become a punch line and a punching bag. It starts with having a whole bunch of well-publicized widely shared posts calling them “crackpots” and “abusive” and “autistic white men” without anybody countering them, until finally we end up in about the same position as, say, Objectivism. Having all of those be wrong is no defense, unless somebody turns it into such. If no one makes it reputationally costly to lie, people will keep lying. The negative affect builds up more and more, and the people who always wanted to hate us anyway because we’re a little bit weird say “Oh, phew, we can hate them now”, and then I and all my friends get hated and dehumanized, the prestigious establishment people jump ship, and there’s no way to ever climb out of the pit. All you need for this to happen is one or two devoted detractors, and boy do we have them.

That seems to leave only two choices.

First, give up on ever having the support of important institutions like journalism and academia and business, slide into the black hole, and accept decent and interesting conversations with other black hole denizens as a consolation prize while also losing the chance at real influence or attracting people not already part of the movement.

Or, second, call out every single bad argument, make the insults and mistruths reputationally costly enough that people think at least a little before doing them – and end up with a reputation for being nitpicky, confrontational and fanatical all the time.

(or, as the old Tumblr saying goes, “STOP GETTING SO DEFENSIVE EVERY TIME I ATTACK YOU!”)

I don’t know any third solution. If somebody does, I would really like to hear it.

This entry was posted in Uncategorized. Bookmark the permalink.
← Figure/Ground Illusions
Links 8/15: Linkety-Split →

623 Responses to My Id On Defensiveness

Reverse order
  1. Troy Rex says:
    August 15, 2015 at 4:41 pm

    I think the best strategy would be the one most people with reputations to protect follow, a strategy to which this blog conforms.

    That is, you engage with the critics enough to fight back, but you also mainly keep talking about all the things that make you reputable in the first place, and try to keep yourself above the fray a little bit. You see this tactic with public officials and with scholars, who keep on talking about “my plan to make America great” or “continuing to investigate the religious economics of the 18th Century” or whatever, while engaging with their critics.

    If the bulk of what you produce comes to be about the controversy, then your critics have defined the conversation. I admit this trap is much harder to avoid if the critics are persistent and loud and pointed, like Scholar B was.

    This blog conforms to this strategy because although you do write very long posts on controversial areas (with regretful tags attached), much of the time you are producing data-based commentary on a range of topics. This commentary has established you as a respectable writer, so that Vox people (populi?) have referenced your work, etc.

    I really like your analysis of an event horizon for projective identification. In the back of my mind, I’d forgotten to apply politics to group reputation – of course, a group’s reputation will be the result of both politics and of the merits (or our opinion of the merits) of what they really believe.

    • haishan says:
      August 15, 2015 at 8:43 pm

      Scott has done very poorly at this for the past couple weeks, though. Since the beginning of August, there’s been: a post on summary statistics; a post defending himself/Yudkowsky from Hallquist; an open thread; a links post; a post kind of about Gary Taubes but really about defending an old Yudkowsky essay; a book review; a post defending AI risk/MIRI from Dylan Matthews; and now two posts that are meta-level defensiveness. That’s two posts with actual content — three if you count the links post — versus five defensive posts.

      • Daniel H says:
        August 16, 2015 at 3:27 am

        That seems to be a slightly uncharitable ratio, but the point stands even with my tally. I would count what you call the Taubes post as content, since most of it was generally applicable and he used the Taubes case more as a background example than the content of the post. I also think these two meta posts were both a relatively even mix of defense and content. Even counting that way, though, you get 4-or-5 content to 3 defensive.

    • Connor Flexman says:
      August 15, 2015 at 10:10 pm

      This seems like a broadly countersignaling strategy: you are above the haters. Most people with reputations to protect are already doing well enough to countersignal, but I think Alexander’s point is that the rationalist and EA movements are questionably not to this level yet. I still think your idea might be worth pursuing, and generally looks good to outsiders, but if you guess wrong it’s definitely plausible that these negatives memes would spread without anyone pruning them.

      • LCL says:
        August 16, 2015 at 7:46 am

        Well it’s a “countersignaling strategy” to the extent that you’re acting like your ideas can stand up on their own against poorly formed or toxic critiques. But what if you’re not acting? I think that’s the actual expectation – to honestly think your ideas can stand up on their own against opponents of that sort.

        The urge to engage in point-by-point refutations – defensiveness, basically – is one I think you should resist. If a critique is valid and powerful enough to be worth responding to, then it’s worth engaging with (as opposed to defending against). If it’s not, then it’s not. Defensiveness shows a lack of confidence either in the quality of your ideas or in your audience’s discernment.

        • Hyzenthlay says:
          August 18, 2015 at 12:16 am

          It’s all about striking a balance. It’s definitely possible to spend too much time on defending oneself and one’s views, but I personally appreciate the point-by-point refutations of criticisms. Even if those type of arguments tend to be a hallmark of the less powerful and can therefore make you look insecure, I believe they are necessary.

          As an example, look at atheism. Atheists used to be a tiny minority with no social clout and thus had no choice but to use painstaking, detailed logic to address every ridiculous criticism lobbed against them. But that painstaking logic eventually won people over, and being an atheist is no longer considered nearly as weird or threatening. In fact, it seems like the doors have been flung wide open and there’s a lot more making fun of religion and less painstaking logic. That seems to be a side-effect of getting bigger and more powerful.

          Same with feminism. I think there was a time when feminists were genuinely a lot smarter than the average person, and had to be, because they were painstakingly dismantling a lot of basic assumptions about gender, and unless they backed it up with something they’d be dismissed as total loons. And now, well…

          Mainstream/powerful belief systems can afford to not bother with actual arguments and just rely on their inertia and on shaming those who disagree. For smaller belief systems that are teetering on the edge of the black hole, those kind of nitty-gritty logical arguments are the only thing that will keep them from falling off, and will eventually push them toward a position of power where they can become poisoned with complacency and intellectual laziness and then the cycle starts over again.

          • Jules.LT says:
            August 18, 2015 at 1:01 pm

            I don’t think I’d count painstaking logical argumentation as one of the main factors that made atheism more widespread nowadays…

          • Hyzenthlay says:
            August 18, 2015 at 2:25 pm

            Maybe I’m naive, but I think a group needs to have at least some logical arguments before they gain any kind of traction or exposure beyond a tiny, insular community.

            Then once the group gets large enough to have some kind of mainstream visibility, it gets picked up and spread further by memes that have little to do with logic.

    • Troy Rex says:
      August 15, 2015 at 11:36 pm

      @haishan – very fair point, and so maybe it’s a good thing Scott’s done an explicitly defensive (or meta-level defensive) post. Now that he’s raised the issue of general strategy, we can tell him what he ought to write. 😉 Back to the content mines for him! would be my recommendation.

      @Connor Flexman – I like the timing issue you raise. When is a movement (or person) well-established enough for a counter-signaling strategy – or a strategy at least partially composed of counter-signaling – to become effective? If you don’t stand up for yourself, you might not get to rest on your reputation, because you won’t have one! Still, especially for the EA movement, it seems to be attracting negative commentary precisely because it’s moving up in the world. Might be a good time to keep doing what it’s doing.

  2. Zykrom says:
    August 15, 2015 at 4:42 pm

    Is “become the sort of group that doesn’t collapse under this sort of pressure” an option?

    It’s hard to find anyone with a kind word for Scientology, but they still have public proponents and money and power last time I checked. Same goes for Mormonism to a much lesser degree.

    • Athrelon says:
      August 15, 2015 at 4:55 pm

      In other words, “acquire status sovereignty.” Be the kind of group that has enough of an internal status economy that even the Ross Douthats of the world won’t feel the need to leave to protect their accumulated generalized status. It’s not a bad plan – see the Amish and the Mormons you mentioned; see also starving academics (who opted for the academic status ladder rather than the money status ladder). It’s also extremely hard.

      We’re working on it.

      PS. you might enjoy Vladimir’s argument that the loss of status sovereignty is precisely what caused the Soviet collapse: http://www.xenosystems.net/coming-attractions/#comment-1161

      • SeekingOmniscience says:
        August 15, 2015 at 5:56 pm

        There is an additional potential advantage to this solution, I think.

        Given that the people in the black hole may have more cause to be reasonable, as mentioned above, interacting with them and letting status grow out of these interactions could have a *much* higher ratio of substance-to-bs than trying to maintain status through interactions with people outside of the black hole. And so it could just be more productive, and enjoyable.

        If what’s pushing you into the black hole is basically irrational, then just falling in and then making a little idyllic land of reason — or at least, a relatively idyllic land of reasonable people — is perhaps a better use of time. Maybe.

        • Eggo says:
          August 15, 2015 at 6:44 pm

          Isn’t that basically the strategy of the NRX “passivists”? Make a Black Hole Kingdom and wait for the crazy universe outside to inevitably crumble?

          • nydwracu says:
            August 15, 2015 at 9:20 pm

            The problem with NRx is that it didn’t try to avoid drawing attention to itself. If it’s not one of the twelve examples, it’s at least in the same ballpark.

        • Stefan Drinic says:
          August 16, 2015 at 9:16 am

          This seems dubious. Taken to its logical extrame, this implies that the public might get more sympathetic to nazis and pedophiles if those two groups were to have otherwise very pleasant conversations about art and literature, and have open threads and such with really funny articles and whatnot in them.

          I just don’t see things work out that way.

          • eh says:
            August 18, 2015 at 6:45 am

            I was about to suggest that the general public is growing more sympathetic towards Nazis, but I couldn’t find much evidence for a long-lasting significant upwards trend in any metric. Even Google searches for “Mein Kampf” are decreasing.

            I’ve no idea how to measure attitudes towards paedophilia over the decades. Anyone?

      • notes says:
        August 15, 2015 at 8:49 pm

        Status sovereignty is one option — creating more valuable internal awards of status, sufficient to reduce or eliminate the risk of moderates being pressured out.

        Another option is the converse: devaluing the wider world’s reputations. That has sometimes come in the form of religion (‘whatever people say, God will know the truth’), and has sometimes come in a view toward posterity (‘History will vindicate me.’)

        Sometimes both. Either way, cultivating outcome-independence helps harden against this particular threat.

    • Lambert says:
      August 15, 2015 at 4:57 pm

      I am somewhat doubtful that ‘replicate Scientology’ is a viable option.
      For a movement like rationalism, having kind words, or at least having ideas accepted, is a (the?) primary objective. Money and power are much lesser considerations.

      • EarnestPeer says:
        August 17, 2015 at 7:51 am

        Yeah, I’m pretty sure Scientology only gets to do that because continuing to exist is their main objective. They’ve set up a giant abusive group with no other goal. I don’t think that’s possible here, nevermind worth wanting.

    • Viliam says:
      August 16, 2015 at 1:55 pm

      Scientologists are prone to use lawyers, blackmail, and allegedly even violence against their critics.

      It is easier to win a verbal fight if you also bring a gun.

  3. Not Robin Hanson says:
    August 15, 2015 at 4:44 pm

    Nitpick:

    Their supporters will be banned on site from all decent online venues.

    While “on site” is technically appropriate, I doubt you were intending to go for the pun there.

    • Daniel Armak says:
      August 15, 2015 at 4:58 pm

      When I read that I felt pretty sure it was intentional.

      Lo, by the power of Science, I have made my prediction, I perform the experiment: Scott Alexander, I call on you to reveal to us Truth! (Beauty optional.)

      • Not Robin Hanson says:
        August 15, 2015 at 5:16 pm

        To me it doesn’t have enough “punch” to be intentional. But maybe I’m just typical-minding.

        OP will surely deliver!

        • Roz says:
          August 15, 2015 at 6:01 pm

          Projective identification, accuse Scott of making a pun, and thereby make it turn into a pun.

          • Not Robin Hanson says:
            August 15, 2015 at 6:11 pm

            If a context-appropriate homophone falls in a sentence but nobody hears it, is it a pun?

            Are there punny sentences, or are there merely punny interpretations of sentences?

          • Daniel Armak says:
            August 16, 2015 at 12:49 pm

            If two people hear the same word A, and interpret it as punning on different words B and C, while the speaker intended a non-punning word D, how many puns are there?

  4. Raemon says:
    August 15, 2015 at 4:59 pm

    This doesn’t really apply to Matthew’s article, since that was widely circulated. But honestly, I wouldn’t have heard of Topher’s article if you hadn’t commented on it. (I also wouldn’t have heard of Neo-reaction if you hadn’t commented on it).

    I’m not sure how big each of those followings are, but I think a general rule of thumb is “if your have a larger readership than the person criticizing you, responding to the criticism basically is net-negative.” My vague impression is that Neoreaction gained more power and respectability by being talked about on Slatestar, and that talking about “we’re not a cult and here’s why” generally increases the perception that something is culty.

    If someone is making criticisms that you think would be *worth addressing even if the criticizer had never existed* then it’s worth addressing those criticisms. If the criticizer has a bigger megaphone than you, it’s *possible* that it’s correct to respond, but I think it’s more likely that it’s better to get a bigger megaphone yourself and keep talking about the things that are actually important to you in the first place.

    (For example, as someone who’s side-job is creating rituals, I get called Cultish with some frequency. Sometimes I think the criticisms are fair, and I respond with the specific ways I’m addressing them. Sometimes the criticism are just scare mongering, and I ignore them, which results in me getting some free publicity. Meanwhile I keep talking confidently about why ritual is important and useful and what I’ve learned about it, which is what I actually want to talk about anyway)

    • Tanadrin says:
      August 15, 2015 at 5:19 pm

      On the other hand, I think if you’re far enough outside the mainstream, you’re extra-vulnerable to accusations of (say) cultishness, whether you actually resemble a cult or not. The rationalist (and to a lesser extent, effective altruist) project is sufficiently unusual that most outsiders on first encountering it are not going to know what to make of it. If there’s somebody there, even if they have a small audience, going “this is weird/nonsense/a cult,” I suspect they’re going to be much more effective than they would if they were ascribing those traits to a group which fit more readily into people’s preconceived notions. In that circumstance, I think it makes sense to respond to criticisms, since people who might otherwise be interested in a movement but don’t quite know what to make of it are going to go looking for outside opinions to try to understand that movement better.

    • Benito says:
      August 15, 2015 at 6:51 pm

      Agreement, but Topher is sufficiently well-known that he gave a talk at EA Global. And I’d already read his post, and it felt like all of the criticisms were not well-intentioned but I didn’t really refute them in mind, so I am personally very happy that Scott dissected it.

      • Buck says:
        August 15, 2015 at 7:55 pm

        He didn’t give a talk at EA Global, he just talked quickly about him employer, Quixey.

      • David Moss says:
        August 17, 2015 at 5:57 am

        Also “bigger readership” only has limited applicability here. If an idea that x is full of elitist white males spreads* through a network of like-minded individuals, all telling each other that, or forming the impression for themselves, it doesn’t matter than none of them have a ‘readership’ at all, the idea can still become utterly pervasive and needs some challenging.

    • gattsuru says:
      August 15, 2015 at 6:52 pm

      … I think a general rule of thumb is “if your have a larger readership than the person criticizing you, responding to the criticism basically is net-negative.” My vague impression is that Neoreaction gained more power and respectability by being talked about on Slatestar, and that talking about “we’re not a cult and here’s why” generally increases the perception that something is culty.

      I’d caution against conflating correlation with causation. You’d see exactly the same results were the target group already increasing in influence, simply because there’d be more folk responding as publicity improves. The “we’re not a cult and here’s why” articles, for example, did not come as early in the chain of events as one would expect.

      There’s a certain truth where the Streisand and related effect tend to favor less well-known people — fighting a story necessarily means repeating at least the false parts. But the other side of things is that there’s a huge amount of ability for whoever’s got the bigger megaphone to demonstrate exactly how bizarrely stupid a smaller group can be, even if that’s not actually true. This can lead to rather ridiculous results — my personal favorite being where a Slate author, defending an article written to portray LessWrongers as bizarre and crazy outsiders, defended not contacting anyone /from/ LessWrong by comparing Yudkowsky to a famous film director — but the sobering part is that these flaws are often only obvious to folk already familiar with the target.

      But even outside of obviously questionable decisions like /that/, the first mover still get to define the battlefield. LessWrong becomes about Roko, even if very few LessWrongers care about or even understand the point Roko was trying to bring up; NRx has to bypass the accusations of racism or monarchy cargo cults; the ant tribe becomes about women.

      • nydwracu says:
        August 15, 2015 at 9:19 pm

        The larger megaphone gets to define the battlefield, and it’s often possible to do this without outright lying, which makes it much harder to call them on it.

        When the group with the smaller megaphone get harassed, when they get fired for contact with ants, when they get bomb threats, etc., word goes around in the ant and ant-sympathetic media, and that’s it. When the group with the larger megaphone get harassed, that’s another data point for the narrative, promoted by the entirety of the larger megaphone, that the group with the smaller megaphone consists of evil harassers. (It doesn’t need to be the entire group with the larger megaphone that gets the signal-boosting power, of course — you could be selective and try to play (for example) the damsel-in-distress trope in order to increase the potency of the narrative.)

        That’s not to say that there’s never any reason to lie — it’s risky, but it can be a way to test the waters. If you can lie and get away with it — if you can, let’s say, falsely claim to have left your house and gone into hiding — then you know you have power, and so does everyone who pays enough attention to notice the lie.

    • Scott Alexander says:
      August 15, 2015 at 7:06 pm

      I originally tried to avoid responding to Topher’s article, but a lot of people were sharing it on Facebook and eventually I figured it had reached the point where I might as well.

      Part of the problem – and this is a separate post – is that some groups reach a point where they have a lot of members who seem to be more interested in repeating and signal-boosting criticism of the group than praise of the group. I think LW got to this point a while ago, and EA is reaching it. This is not healthy but I don’t know how to stop it.

      • TheAncientGeek says:
        August 16, 2015 at 6:21 am

        Which is to say, they don’t feel the need keep repeating that the things that don’t need fixing, don’t need fixing — but do feel the need to keep pointing out that what’s broken needs fixing.

        That perhaps doesn’t convey the right message to outsiders. Perhaps it was better when conversations were private by default.

      • Viliam says:
        August 16, 2015 at 2:22 pm

        This is not healthy but I don’t know how to stop it.

        I believe you have already done a great job with the articles about bravery debates. Now at least the people who want to get contrarian points don’t start their comments saying “I know this will cost me a lot of karma” when everyone smart enough knows that posting a clever contrarian argument on LW will get you positive karma — either immediately, or first you wil get a downvote or two and then someone will say “guys, I don’t know why this comment is downvoted; it is a smart criticism and we need more of that to avoid becoming a cult, so I am going to upvote it” and the karma immediately jumps high.

        Eliezer wrote a bit about the sin of underconfidence. Maybe it would be worth saying that it applies not only to individuals, but also to groups.

        The accusation of LW “repeating and signal-boosting criticism” should be more specific. There are some recent examples that I remember: that LW quality is dropping, that CFAR doesn’t seem to produce anything impressive.

        On the other hand, there was a lot of criticism in the past that I don’t remember repeated recently. We used to worry about what RationalWiki writes about us; the articles are still there, no one cares anymore. We used to worry that maybe we are nerdy white men who make the website unattractive to women and minorieties; I haven’t heard this complaint recently either. No one even mentions the b*s*l*sk anymore (maybe all people who were scared of it are now too busy building it). When was the last debate whether LW is cultish? I don’t rememeber anymore.

        So, some criticism survives and gets signal-boosted, but other criticism gets ignored. What makes the difference? It is just old stuff vs. new stuff, that after certain amount of signal boost the topic doesn’t provide contrarian points anymore?

        • RCF says:
          August 17, 2015 at 12:04 am

          “when everyone smart enough knows that posting a clever contrarian argument on LW will get you positive karma”

          But what about not-particularly-clever-but-still-addressing-a-legitimate-problem arguments? Are only eloquent people allowed to bring up problems?

          • Protagoras says:
            August 17, 2015 at 12:16 am

            Pretty much. But posts that defend LW also tend not to get many upvotes if they lack eloquence, so while it is certainly an issue, I’m not sure it has much relevance to the present topic.

  5. Muga Sofer says:
    August 15, 2015 at 4:59 pm

    >Me, I’ve always thought of it the same was as Aristotle: man is the rational animal.

    Extra “was” there, I think.

    • David Friedman says:
      August 15, 2015 at 5:43 pm

      typo for “way” is my guess.

  6. E. Harding says:
    August 15, 2015 at 5:03 pm

    “To dehumanize them is to say their ideas don’t count, they can’t be reasoned with, they no longer have a place at the table of rational discussion.”
    -Ah, but, Scott, there are millions of people out there who can’t be reasoned with (on both the Left and Right, and everywhere in between), at least on certain issues. Is this a “concentrate on the sin, not the sinner” post/thing, or is there something more to it?

    Also, I would have preferred more concrete, actual cases to hypotheticals in this post. The concrete cases are much more useful to examine, as they’re not arguments from fictional evidence.

    • David Friedman says:
      August 15, 2015 at 5:52 pm

      There are lots of people who cannot be reasoned with. But there are few groups that contain only people who cannot be reasoned with, so when someone takes the position “there is no point trying to reason with these people,” the most likely explanation is that he doesn’t want to be reasoned with.

      • Seth says:
        August 15, 2015 at 7:20 pm

        I’d contend the major problem is not literally “there are zero people (in the group) who can be reasoned with”, but more along the lines of “the structural incentives give enormous power to those of the group who can’t be reasoned with, which will be used to attack the people outside trying to reason with the group, and also to keep in line people inside the group who may do such reasoning with outsiders”. Similarly, the people who can be reasoned with may have very little power overall in the group.

        Relatively noncontroversial example: There are some Creationists who can be educated as to why it’s not science. But Creationism as a movement has much more to do with overall religious politics than pure education in isolation. Attempting to defuse it solely by individually educating all Creationists is a fool’s errand.

        • Zorgon says:
          August 15, 2015 at 10:39 pm

          I agree with you about the dynamics in question, but I disagree about the intentions of the people claiming “there are no reasonable people in Group X”.

          I think a lot of people in !X, particularly those adjacent to X, are aware of the phenomena you’re taking about; but when some issues an absolute negative about communicating with a group, my immediate assumption is always the same as Scott’s above – they are engaging in group politics and wish to attack The Enemy (and raise their own status in so doing) in the most efficient manner possible. The phenomena you mention merely acts as a convenient excuse.

      • Murphy says:
        August 17, 2015 at 5:49 am

        I’d say some groups attract more of the kind who can’t and not just .

        Non-trivial groups of people who will insist that the only reason their powers of telepathy aren’t working is that you personally are broadcasting too much negativity in the room.

        Non-trivial groups of people who will insist that crystals thrice blessed by a druid make plants grow better and heal wounds faster but will accuse you of “western style thinking” if you ask whether they’ve ever tried testing it with crystals in some plant pots but not others.

        Hell, there are non-trivial groups of people who will insist that the entire concept of “reasoning” and “facts” are oppressive tools of their outgroup created only to oppress them.

        There are groups who are genuinely anti-reason. Not in a horrible way, may of their members can be lovely people but they just don’t have much of an overlapping way of thinking.

    • Scott Alexander says:
      August 15, 2015 at 7:07 pm

      I specifically avoided concrete examples because all of them are mind-killing, would have been met with “how dare you suggest this group doesn’t deserve dehumanization”, or would have turned the comments into being about those movements rather than my point.

      • Nita says:
        August 16, 2015 at 3:01 am

        Do you really see no difference between “this group deserves to lose some members because its ideas are bad” and “the members of this group deserve to be dehumanized”?

        The OP also struck me as speaking about groups almost as if they were people. No one’s hurling people into black holes. I don’t understand why I should always consider a group becoming less popular a morally bad outcome, regardless of its object-level beliefs or effects.

        • FacelessCraven says:
          August 16, 2015 at 3:31 am

          @Nita – “Do you really see no difference between “this group deserves to lose some members because its ideas are bad” and “the members of this group deserve to be dehumanized”?”

          …In the spirit of our exchange in the last thread, I think part of the difference in question is between a group that alienates the public through its own actions, and a group whose alienation is helped along by its adversaries highlighting the worst in it and concealing the best, and generally doing what they can to make it impossible for it to get a fair hearing.

          If I listen to someone’s views, conclude they are repugnant, and lose respect for them, that’s one thing. If I then write a polemic about why that person is evil and that no one intelligent should waste their time listening to them, that’s something else. The latter is certainly an effective tactic if your goal is to defeat your ideological opponents. It also pretty much inevitably leads to massive abuse.

          Some views don’t seem to be worth respecting. Some views are sufficiently monstrous that holding them makes you a monster. I don’t think there are any views that make a monster sufficiently monstrous that, provided they’re willing to attempt to frame their ideas in a civil manner, responding in kind makes you a monster too.

          “I don’t understand why I should always consider a group becoming less popular a morally bad outcome, regardless of its object-level beliefs or effects.”

          Becoming less popular isn’t the bad outcome. It’s how that happens that matters. If your group can be made revolting to people who have never encountered it first-hand, that’s generally a bad sign.

          “No one’s hurling people into black holes.”

          At least three examples spring immediately to mind, but I think Scott would rather we not discuss specifics. I guess it depends what you mean by “hurling into a black hole.” How would you define it?

          • sweeneyrod says:
            August 16, 2015 at 4:47 am

            “If your group can be made revolting to people who have never encountered it first-hand, that’s generally a bad sign.”

            I’ve not met any members of the KKK and I don’t really want to. I don’t think that’s irrational.

          • Nita says:
            August 16, 2015 at 4:54 am

            I agree that it’s possible to vilify a group unfairly, and that this is bad behaviour. On the other hand, it’s also possible to honestly criticize a group’s ideas and get labeled An Evil Enemy Trying To Destroy Us.

            Is it OK to publish any criticism at all, or should it be forbidden, to let every person form their opinion of every group solely from personal experience?

            (I’m not sure how one would “conceal the best” in some group, btw — is it a thing people do?)

            And you talk of someone calling people evil monsters, but that doesn’t match the instances that Scott got defensive about. E.g., Christopher Hallquist didn’t write “LW-rationalists are evil monsters!”, he accused them of undervaluing the mainstream scientific process to make their own advice shine brighter. Whether he is right or wrong, he’s certainly treating rationalists like human beings.

          • MicaiahC says:
            August 16, 2015 at 5:02 am

            Sweeney: Signal boosting this article because it’s amazing.

            If you find it surprising that they can be reasoned with, and that Davis could have made it out alive and mostly unharmed, I think you should acknowledge one of 1) the KKK aren’t as dangerous as you perceive 2) talking to them, no matter how unpleasant might have on net positive effects in limited circumstances or 3) you just don’t like them very much for what they think, and basically don’t wish to associate with them because they’re gross.

            I’m being a bit flippant here, there are less absurd graduations of my points 1, 2 and 3 here as well as points I haven’t covered. But really, why don’t you want to meet a member, and does an actual account of meeting one change your mind?

          • FacelessCraven says:
            August 16, 2015 at 6:08 am

            @SweeneyRod – “I’ve not met any members of the KKK and I don’t really want to. I don’t think that’s irrational.”

            As far as I know, I’ve never met a member of the KKK either. I have encountered things that their members have written or drawn, and the signs they wave at their marches, and based on those I am comfortable drawing conclusions about their movement. If some member of the KKK wishes to explain why they’re deeply misunderstood and are actually a force of good in their communities, let them. It’s going to be a hard sell, though.

            @Nita – “Is it OK to publish any criticism at all, or should it be forbidden, to let every person form their opinion of every group solely from personal experience?”

            Criticism: “this guy is dead wrong, and here’s why.”
            What We Are Talking About Here: “This guy isn’t just wrong, he’s evil, and you’d be a fool to listen to anything he says.”

            One is engaging in debate, the other is attempting to close off the possibility of debate. This doesn’t seem like a difficult distinction to make.

            “(I’m not sure how one would “conceal the best” in some group, btw — is it a thing people do?)”
            It is a thing people do. For an example that is probably safe:
            https://slatestarcodex.com/2013/12/23/we-are-all-msscribe/
            See also: “A lie gets halfway around the world before the truth gets its boots on.”
            Make the first impression your audience gets of a target a ridiculous straw-man caricature. Reach your audience before the target can, get your narrative in place before they even reach the field, and no one will listen to anything they have to say, even if they’re telling the truth and you are lying.

            You’ve honestly never seen this happen?

            “And you talk of someone calling people evil monsters, but that doesn’t match the instances that Scott got defensive about.”

            That’s the conversation from the last post leaking into this one. It seems to me that both discussions are about the same principle. Namely, that using reasoned argument to advocate evil is more acceptable than “fighting dirty” to stop people from advocating evil.

          • Nita says:
            August 16, 2015 at 6:38 am

            I don’t think saying “those ideas are evil” is always fighting dirty. If anything, to me

            A: “don’t listen to those people because their ideas are bad”

            seems less damaging to the collective search for good ideas than

            B: “don’t listen to those ideas because their people are bad”.

            I don’t like how Scott seems to conflate the two and accuse people of saying both even when they’ve only been saying A.

            (Examples of A: “Listening to Marxists / neoreactionaries / Christians is a waste of time because they’re advocating for waging class war / punishing gay people / worshipping an Unfriendly Supernatural Intelligence.”)

            (Examples of B: “How can you defend LW-rationalism / feminism / mens rights when Eliezer / Amanda Marcotte / Paul Elam is such a jerk?!”)

          • FacelessCraven says:
            August 16, 2015 at 7:06 am

            @Nita – ”
            A: “don’t listen to those people because their ideas are bad”
            B: “don’t listen to those ideas because their people are bad”.
            ”

            Not listening to them and not listening to their ideas are the same thing, aren’t they? And a person with evil beliefs and an evil person are pretty much the same thing, yes?

            Example A is straw men, and example B is ad hominems. Why would one be preferable to the other? Both insulate your audience from anything the person in question says, so both are open to abuse on the MsScribe model. One is unfair to a group, the other is unfair to a person.

            …I’m really not getting the difference. Both seem pretty bad, and pretty similar.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            August 16, 2015 at 8:16 am

            @FacelessCraven:
            But when they were thrown into the black hole the KKK was an organization that did actual, physical violence to black people, existed for the purpose of terrifying them, and had been that way since inception.

            Davis is a hero, and took the opportunity of being humanized to his enemy. We should never forget that the people in the KKK are humans.

            But, if we don’t get to call what the KKK did “evil” then evil doesn’t exist.

          • Nita says:
            August 16, 2015 at 9:42 am

            @ FacelessCraven

            a person with evil beliefs and an evil person are pretty much the same thing, yes?

            No, not at all! E.g., if neoreactionaries ever start putting their grand ideas into action, they will (most likely) become evil people. For now, they are merely people who hold and popularize evil beliefs. Similarly, while Lenin was writing pamphlets for his underground revolutionary organization, he probably had some evil beliefs. But when he started the Red Terror, he became an evil person.

            Example A is straw men, and example B is ad hominems. Why would one be preferable to the other? Both insulate your audience from anything the person in question says

            No, they don’t. In both cases, you can check whether the critic has good evidence. In case A, if you find the evidence valid, you can safely agree with the critic.

            In case B, even if the individuals in question have indeed acted badly, their ideas could still be true / helpful / defensible. But the critic, by smuggling in the premise “anything a bad person believes is bad”, is trying to make you overlook that possibility.

          • Jiro says:
            August 16, 2015 at 11:29 am

            I’ve not met any members of the KKK and I don’t really want to. I don’t think that’s irrational.

            I don’t think this counts. I wouldn’t need an opponent to tell me how bad the KKK is; just listening to their own statements about themselves would be enough. It’s not as if (when allowed to speak freely, at least) the KKK hides what it believes in.

          • David Friedman says:
            August 16, 2015 at 2:40 pm

            On the meeting a KKK member substhread, a possibly relevant story:

            Many years ago, I was invited to a conference in Paris–I no longer remember the topic. A little before it was to happen, a bunch of American participants pulled out in protest of the fact that one of the French participants was, by their account, a fascist.

            My reaction was that if he was a fascist that was a reason to go—I had never met a fascist, their ideas had been sufficiently persuasive to be supported by large numbers of people, some surely intelligent, so it would be interesting to talk to one and see if I could understand why people had believed in them.

            The “fascist” withdrew in counter protest, but I went to the conference and arranged to have dinner with him. He wasn’t a fascist, was a member of Le Pen’s party. His basic view was that classical antiquity, I think specifically the early Roman Empire, had been the high point of European civilization and it had been going downhill since, in large part due to the bad influence of Christianity. His picture of the U.S., which I don’t think he had ever visited, was wall to wall MacDonalds, so I enjoyed telling him about the SCA (historical recreation from the Middle Ages and Renaissance—one of my long time hobbies).

            I don’t know if meeting me changed his views–I don’t think I have seen him since and no longer remember his name. But talking to him was an interesting and educational experience for me, expanding my view of the views it was possible for an intelligent person with a very different background to hold.

          • Tracy W says:
            August 16, 2015 at 4:02 pm

            @Nita, jumping in again:

            A: “don’t listen to those people because their ideas are bad”

            This is a non-sequitor of an argument. As J. S. Mills argued at length in chapter 2 of his book On Liberty, even when ideas are wrong, engaging with them improves our own understanding of the right ideas.

          • FacelessCraven says:
            August 16, 2015 at 5:42 pm

            @HeelBearCub – “But, if we don’t get to call what the KKK did “evil” then evil doesn’t exist.”

            The KKK is evil. That doesn’t make people who are willing to reason with them or talk to them evil as well. Evil is not infectious like the flu.

            @Nita – Could we back up a bit to your previous formulation?

            ”
            A: “don’t listen to those people because their ideas are bad”
            B: “don’t listen to those ideas because their people are bad”.
            ”
            The symmetry is pleasing, but could we taboo “listen”?

            A: “these people’s ideas lead to bad outcomes. Don’t follow their advice.”
            B: “these people are bad people, so you should ignore anything they say.”
            …Would that be a fair reformulation?

            “No, not at all! E.g., if neoreactionaries ever start putting their grand ideas into action, they will (most likely) become evil people.”

            I see evil more as a quality you have regardless of whether you’ve been able to act on it. Evil is in the heart, not the hand. “if your right eye causes you to sin, gouge it out” is intended as a reducto ad absurdum, not practical advice.

            “No, they don’t. In both cases, you can check whether the critic has good evidence.”

            “Good evidence”, sooner or later, involves the people in question being able to express their ideas. That is harder to do when people will accuse you of being evil for letting the evil people make their case. Again, it gets back to whether silencing/attacking people for advocating evil is better or worse than actually advocating evil. I think it’s better to let people advocate evil than it is to silence evil-advocates.

            I also think that letting people talk will probably reduce the likelihood of them taking evil action, rather than increasing it.

          • hc says:
            August 17, 2015 at 12:59 am

            PART 1: WP > WS

            Haven’t you guys heard of the astounding concept of white-positivity written by Adashanti?

            White-positivity is NOT white-supremacy, my man. White Supremacy is the idea that “white” people are the best people on the planet and that they should hurt people of other races.

            White-Positivity is the idea that white people are fine how they are and can do whatever they want like every other race.. completely different.

            Surprised anyone thought white-positivity and white-supremacy were the same thing.. seems kind of ignorant.

            PART 2: FUGLY

            If your “opponent” fights fugly, uh, you better make sure you respond in favor. Get “fugly” haha.

            If my opponent were to refer to my group of choice as a “cult,” I would simply respond with the exact same insult in the same degree, not more however. In this and in excess of his cult we see that he has a cult of his own… it is not important what the cult is. Simply that his cult be given reference and his term ignored. “Becuz sometimes ya gotta get fugly.”

            PART 3: IDIOTS IN ALL SIDES

            The black hole is not the same as the “Fun Zone.” The Fun Zone is where tight bros who know what’s what go to shoot hoops and do dunks. They are also capable of having a blast. No posers are allowed though. Posers suck, we all know it haha.

            The black hole is where idiots go to get whooped on by their own crippling sense of inferiority. Yeah, those ‘tards actually dehumanized themselves. F em. That’s what I say. But remember, that means F you. F me. F all of us. At the same time, that just means no “hoops for the loops.” Those ‘tards should have gone to the Fun Zone and instead they choose to suck at the teat of they abusive mommy.

            PART 4: SELF-HELP

            There is an idea of “respectability.” For instance, in my above posts when I said “fugly,” I bet someone out there thought I was trolling. We see Donald Trump on the news and everyone thinks its “obvious” that he is a complete joke. I read the New Yorker recently and they had about 100 little cartoons scattered throughout the magazine making him look like a clown. That’s the whole strategy right now for Bill Maher and some of those folks.

            So, in some sense, am I becoming a clown in order to satiate the never-ending sexual desire of MSNBC newscasters? Or, in some other sense, has my post become clownlike out of a sense of laughter or humor. That the very accusation of clownery upon me originates from a place which in and of itself is clownish. Is this a mockery, sir? Yes. It is a mockery.

            However, is there some point at which a clown must become sexual? Where a clown becomes “respectable” and takes off his paint or something? I’ve been trying to figure it out. It seems like a lot of that is central to what is used to make certain arguments look bad. “It’s not respectable.” But more and more all I see out of the left and its drones and on TV is a funny joke like out of a comedy movie. And on my feeds. It’s quite literally hilarious. But then reality sets in.

            Perhaps people need to laugh more.

          • Nita says:
            August 17, 2015 at 3:36 am

            @ Tracy W

            As J. S. Mills argued at length in chapter 2 of his book On Liberty, even when ideas are wrong, engaging with them improves our own understanding of the right ideas.

            1) Incidentally, Mills followed his own advice and wrote up a rebuttal to Carlyle’s call for re-enslavement. Are folks today reading Carlyle and Mills and making up their minds about slavery on the basis of object-level arguments? Nope, they’re reading Moldbug’s laments about Carlyle being unfairly black-holed by the evil Establishment.

            2) Do you actually fully engage with every idea you come across? Where do you find the time? E.g., there’s an Objectivist commenter downthread arguing that everyone should read Ayn Rand’s books. Most educated Catholics will ask you to digest the works of Thomas Acquinas, a few tomes of thelogy and an essay by the Pope before you dismiss their arguments against premarital sex. Listening to literally everyone is a nice idea, but it doesn’t seem practical in modern context.

            @ FacelessCraven

            The KKK is evil. That doesn’t make people who are willing to reason with them or talk to them evil as well.

            Well, sure? Who’s saying otherwise?

            A: “these people’s ideas lead to bad outcomes. Don’t follow their advice.”
            B: “these people are bad people, so you should ignore anything they say.”
            …Would that be a fair reformulation?

            Yes, that’s what I’m saying — despite the surface similarity, the content is very different.

            I see evil more as a quality you have regardless of whether you’ve been able to act on it.

            So, should the Tsar have executed Lenin back in 1897, before he had harmed anyone, instead of merely exiling him to a remote location? This model of evil doesn’t seem very useful without either clairvoyance or telepathy (or being an omniscient diety).

            “Good evidence”, sooner or later, involves the people in question being able to express their ideas.

            Sure. They don’t have the right to demand that someone else provide them free hosting, though.

            I think it’s better to let people advocate evil than it is to silence evil-advocates.

            Sure, but when someone conflates criticism with silencing, they tread uncomfortably close to silencing criticism.

            I also think that letting people talk will probably reduce the likelihood of them taking evil action, rather than increasing it.

            Well, it depends, but generally — yes. Or rather, any actual persecution will feed into their id’s alarm detectors and let them justify anything as self-defense.

          • houseboatonstyx says:
            August 17, 2015 at 4:02 am

            @ Nita
            They don’t have the right to demand that someone else provide them free hosting, though.

            Someone has remarked that the Internet has no street corners, no Hyde Park — ie no frequented public space where every citizen has the right to speak. It’s all private property. One’s own low-budget website is not much help with no streetcorners to announce it from, no lampposts to post broadsides on.

            So imo it’s only decent courtesy for us to at least link to the opposing viewpoint.

          • brad says:
            August 17, 2015 at 3:50 pm

            @Tracy W

            This is a non-sequitor of an argument. As J. S. Mills argued at length in chapter 2 of his book On Liberty, even when ideas are wrong, engaging with them improves our own understanding of the right ideas.

            Are you familiar with the phenomenon of math cranks? An professor of mathematics, pretty much anywhere, will get long unsolicited manuscripts claiming to have proven some or other famous open problem. One could easily spend all his time carefully going through these manuscripts and pointing out all the errors and otherwise engaging with these members of the public. Would you say that’s worth doing?

            Then, suppose you did. Would it be improper for you to tell your colleagues that they ought not to read manuscript x because it makes no sense, or correspond with its author because she refuses to acknowledge that it makes no sense, the fair thing being to suggest they read it and make up their own minds?

        • Cauê says:
          August 16, 2015 at 3:34 am

          Do you really see no difference between “this group deserves to lose some members because its ideas are bad” and “the members of this group deserve to be dehumanized”?

          I think every idea I disagree with “deserves” to become less popular, and to the extent that a group is defined as “people who believe in that idea”, all of those groups “deserve to lose members”. Where do you think Scott argues against this?

          I see him arguing against saying that “their ideas don’t count, they can’t be reasoned with, they no longer have a place at the table of rational discussion“, and I’m not seeing the conflation.

          • Nita says:
            August 16, 2015 at 5:06 am

            Lots of people pay zero attention to ideas I consider important, and dismiss them out of hand if they can’t simply ignore them. I find this frustrating, but I’m not worried about my physical safety.

            On the other hand, if people started actually dehumanizing me or people like me, I suspect that would feel very different from having my favourite ideas ignored.

          • Cauê says:
            August 16, 2015 at 12:08 pm

            It does. I think we’re all in agreement on that. What I don’t get is why you think Scott “sees no difference”.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            August 16, 2015 at 12:17 pm

            @Cauê:

            Isn’t Scott arguing for never dismissing ideas out of hand, even if they seem to/actually do dehumanize others, because otherwise they might fall victim to the black hole?

            That’s a legitimate question, not a rhetorical one. I really am unsure.

      • tb says:
        August 16, 2015 at 10:29 am

        Now that discussion has developed sufficiently to avoid derailment, would you consider a quick list of the cases you had in mind? Thank you.

      • TheNybbler says:
        August 16, 2015 at 11:02 am

        There’s a problem, though; examples or no, there ARE groups for whom “arrogant”, “fanatical”, “hateful”, and “cultish” are appropriate descriptors.

        There are many groups characteristed by “refusing to tolerate alternative opinions”.

        And there are groups who condone (or commit, e.g. ISIS or whatever today’s acronym for them is) terrorism, bullying, violence, and even rape.

        You can’t tell by the ‘style’ of argument that nasty dehumanizing tactics are being used. You have to look at the substance. And avoiding the ‘style’ of calling people or groups “hateful”, etc. when they actually are amounts to giving them a free pass.

        • Tracy W says:
          August 16, 2015 at 4:05 pm

          I’d rather give someone a free pass than wrongly call a group “hateful”.
          We could do with less hate in this world, not more.

          • TheNybbler says:
            August 16, 2015 at 6:08 pm

            Calling a group “hateful” when they’re hateful doesn’t increase the amount of hate in the world, but giving a free pass to a hateful group certainly has the potential to.

          • Mary says:
            August 16, 2015 at 8:25 pm

            Ah, but how accurate is your judgment of whether a group is hateful?

          • Tracy W says:
            August 17, 2015 at 1:19 am

            @TheNybbler: it seems to me that calling a group “hateful” does increase the amount of hate in this world. Describing a group as that turns me into an outputter of hate.

            It may be possible that even so there are times when it makes tactical sense to apply that word, but as Mary says, consider the chance that you’re wrong.

          • Tracy W says:
            August 17, 2015 at 1:39 am

            @TheNybbler: it seems to me that calling a group “hateful” does increase the amount of hate in this world. Describing a group as that turns me into an outputter of hate.

            It may be possible that even so there are times when it makes tactical sense to apply that word, but as Mary says, consider the possibility that you’re wrong.

    • jimmy says:
      August 16, 2015 at 2:44 pm

      “Ah, but, Scott, there are millions of people out there who can’t be reasoned with”

      There’s definitely quite a bit of truth to that – many people are nontrivial to exceedingly difficult to reason with, and it’s often not practical/worthwhile. *However*, it is absolutely not a “can’t”, and phrasing it that way is a semantic stop sign.

      Until you’ve reasoned people out of things like “irrational” fears and pain, you don’t really know how to reason with people that aren’t trivially easy to reason with, and claims about people being “impossible to reason with” say more about your lack of imagination than about the territory itself.

  7. Ever An Anon says:
    August 15, 2015 at 5:12 pm

    Supposedly SEO experts recommend countering critical blog posts / reviews / comments by burying them under tons and tons of positive ones you make yourself. I’m not sure how true it is but people seem to buy it: look into any multi-level marketing scam and you’ll see a battery of eerily similar articles with titles like “[MLM Name] helped me get started” or “Is [MLM Name] a scam? No!”

    Actual political movements and even militaries are known to pull similar stunts. Add an extra digit to everyone’s Party Number to make our group look bigger. Only hire freakishly tall men, dress them in giant hats, and march them all over the country. Anything to make yourself look bigger and more intimidating.

    I think that a pufferfish kind of strategy, intentionally inflating your group’s percieved wealth size and influence, can probably help in avoiding the black hole. It won’t stop a determined attacker but it might help on the margins.

  8. Anonymous says:
    August 15, 2015 at 5:13 pm

    This heavily reminds me of that page on RationalWiki where a bunch of people declared that rationalism had been shown to be a cult because a leadership figure was insufficiently nice to someone who had started a hateblog about him. Once a group of people dislikes you, any attempt to defend yourself will be regarded as an unprovoked attack. (If you don’t matter as a moral entity, attacking you isn’t a relevant action.) The fact is that when you engage with people who insult you, your writing suffers. You’re still being dogged by some turns of phrase in “untitled” the better part of a year later, and that “punishing defectors” paragraph about Taubes will probably suffer the same fate. The fact is, I strongly doubt that rationalism will go the way you imagine it, because there is no counter-lobby. Nobody’s going to take the time and effort to thoroughly smear rationalism’s name in the public square. Nobody’s even heard of rationalism in the public square.

          • Daniel H says:
            August 16, 2015 at 4:44 am

            I am looking at the Yudkowsky article now. The problems I see with it are that it gives an uncharitable rendering of his views (it gives several reasons that AI foom is unlikely, many of which are either false or based on a poor understanding of AI foom; it says he dislikes mainstream science without clarifying that he thinks it does a better job than most ways people could try to learn but that better is possible; it goes into far more detail on the things it has criticisms for than the things that are praiseworthy), it gives an unfair look at his accomplishments (no, duh, of course he hasn’t released AI code; that’s not the problem he’s working on), and it conflates LessWrong with Eliezer Yudkowsky (implying that he agrees with anything “his followers” say).

            There are other problems with it too, but they mainly fall into one of those categories. The things that don’t include condemning him for holding views that are controversial, condemning him for working on problems that are thus far unsolved, and exaggerating things to the point of being ridiculous while still making the sentences technically true.

            But when people basically say that it is obvious, goes without saying, and hardly needs mentioning that their views are those of the smart, high prestige people and it is obvious, goes without saying, and hardly needs mentioning their opponents views are those of the village idiots then I get so mad that I see red.

            I don’t know why.             Is this just me, or can someone relate to that? Is it possible that this emotional reaction to this strategy really comes from there?
